docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Accuracy is the proximity of measurement results to the accepted value; precision is the degree to which repeated or reproducible measurements under unchanged conditions show the same results.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • BS ISO 5725-1

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data acquired on the same platform but not obtained from the main Sensor itself (usually provided as part of Level 0 Data). They have the primary purpose to serve the processing of main instrument Data (e.g. Position and velocity of platform).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ESA/CEOS?, modified

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Data other than instrument measurements, originating in the instrument itself or from the satellite, required to perform processing of the Data. They include orbit Data, attitude Data, time Information, and spacecraft engineering Data, Calibration Data, Data quality Information, and Data from other instruments or earth system models.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS-ARD PFS template 20220302

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses consisting predominantly of matter processed by humans such as construction wood, bricks, concrete, asphalt, glass or plastics.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: It is the zone in 2D or 3D for which the Information or Data is requested. It can be discontinuous in space, in other words it can consist in the union of many separate zones (e.g., Natural Reserves in Africa, Urban environments, etc.). The attribute indicates a request for spatially complete Data within the AOI zone(s).

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid units Geographical/administrative identifier NUTS3, LAU, Natura 2000 site unitless

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: the layer of gases, commonly known as air, including suspended liquid and solid particles known as aerosols (incl. dust, clouds, snow and ice).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data, which enhance processing, and utilization of main Sensor Data. The auxiliary Data are usually not captured by the same Data collection process or on the same platform as the main Sensor Data. Examples are e.g. meteorological Data received from ECWMF/Met or DEMs. Offices. Auxiliary Data help in Data processing, but are also Data sets in their own right.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• ESA/CEOS?, modified
  • ENMAP Glossary of Terms, https://www.enmap.org/Data/doc/EnMAP_Terms.pdf, 20210624

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Data required to perform processing of Sensor Data which is not obtained from the Sensor itself. Include: (a) Data provided by the spacecraft (e.g. orbit Position and velocity, attitude, instrument house-keeping Data, on-board time), (b) Data not available from on-board sources. EnMAP: (a) Orbit files, attitude files, Calibration Data, instrument house-keeping Data, (b) atmospheric parameters, Reference images.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ENMAP Glossary of Terms, https://www.enmap.org/Data/doc/EnMAP_Terms.pdf, 20210624

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: The Data required for instrument processing, which does not originate in the instrument itself or from the satellite. Some auxiliary Data will be generated in the ground segment, whilst other Data will be provided from external sources.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS-ARD PFS template 20220302

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A single wavelength Value within the sensitivity interval of a spectroradiometric Sensor which represents the respective band. It could be either the mean, the median, the maximum sensitivity, or any other reasonable Value chosen to be representative.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 0.545 μm micrometre (μm), millimetre (mm), centimetre (cm)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses of living organisms, such as vegetation and animals, including dead but still connected parts such as roots, trunks or branches.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Calibration refers to the process of quantitatively defining a system’s (e.g. a Sensor or Model’s) response to known, controlled inputs produced for example by references. In Remote Sensing, it implies the collection of pre-flight and in-flight calibration measurements and in-situ Data that is to be used in the Data calibration processing routine.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Spatial, spatio-temporal zone or temporal unit of geometry with dimensionality greater than 0, associated with a zone.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Cells are the unit of geometry in a DGGS, and the geometry of the region of space-time occupied by a zone is a cell.

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: All changes are tracked here.

docs.title: v0.1
docs.text:
• initial version release
  • errors expected, needs feedback and proofreading

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Distinguishing Feature

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• A characteristic can be inherent or assigned.
  • A characteristic can be qualitative or quantitative.
  • There are various classes of characteristics, such as the following:
  • physical (e.g. mechanical, electrical, chemical, biological);
  • sensory (e.g. relating to smell, touch, taste, sight, hearing);
  • behavioural (e.g. courtesy, honesty, veracity);
  • temporal (e.g. punctuality, reliability, availability);
  • ergonomic (e.g. physiological characteristic or related to human safety);
  • functional (e.g. maximum speed of an aircraft).

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Abstraction of a Property of an Object or of a set of objects.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Characteristics are used for describing concepts.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 1087-1:2000, 3.2.4; ISO 19146:2010(E); https://www.iso.org/standard/20057.html

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The nomenclature used to classify Information into categorical thematic classes (e.g., EUNIS, MAES ecosystems, Corine Land Cover, LCCS).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The probability that the quantity lies in the interval, conditioned on the measuring or modelling assumptions.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: An institutional body, an organisation or programme that provides reliable, trusted (authoritative?) EO Information and that has the financial resources to sustain the provision. It utilizes satellite Data, ground-based measurements, and other sources to generate accurate and timely Data products related to various aspects of the Earth's environment, such as land, atmosphere, oceans, and climate.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: the masses of frozen water, such as sea ice, ice shields, glaciers, and snow.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Value and possibility uncertainty of trait of a specific entity.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Data can be factual (i.e. obtained by observation) or fictional (obtained e.g. through modelling, estimating or assigning), quantitative (continuous) or qualitative (categorical), and analogue or digital (list not exhaustive).
  • Data simply describe entities using certain attributes and are not targeted at a particular use or audience.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The service to disseminate data

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Structured data that is machine readable and can be automatically read and processed by a computer, such as HDF, NetCDF, CSV, JSON, XML, etc.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A legal instrument by which a copyright holder may grant rights over the protected work. Data and content is open if it is subject to an explicitly-applied licence that conforms to the Open Definition. A range of standard open licenses are available, such as the Creative Commons CC-BY licence, which requires only attribution.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CEOS Wiki

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Non-negative interval Quantity of time equal to the difference between the final and initial instants of a time.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The duration is one of the base quantities in the International System of Quantities (ISQ) on which the International System of Units (SI) is based. The term “time” instead of “duration” is often used in this context and also for an infinitesimal duration.
  • For the term “duration”, expressions such as “time” or “time interval” are often used, but the term “time” is not recommended in this sense and the term “time interval” is deprecated in this sense to avoid confusion with the concept of “time interval”.
  • The exact duration of a time scale unit depends on the time scale used. For example, the durations of a year, month, week, day, hour or minute, may depend on when they occur [in a Gregorian calendar, a calendar month can have a duration of 28, 29, 30, or 31 days; in a 24-hour clock, a clock minute can have a duration of 59, 60, or 61 seconds, etc.]. Therefore, the exact duration can only be evaluated if the exact duration of each is known.
  • This definition is closely related to NOTE 1 of the terminological entry “duration” in IEC 60050-113:2011, 113–01–13.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time that an antenna beam spends on a target.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • in the context of radar sensing

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A science domain dealing with technologies and methods of collecting and analyzing observations about the different spheres (Geosphere, Atmosphere, Hydrosphere, Cryosphere, Biosphere, Anthroposphere) of our planet. This includes remote-sensing, such as satellite imagery, as well as in-situ observations, e.g., with ground-based devices.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Earth Observation (EO) can be categorised by Location of the Sensor into space-borne, air-borne, sea-borne, ground-based, underwater and underground EO.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Modified GEO definition GEO (earthobservations.org)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A representation of a phenomenon that can be coded into information. A product serves multiple purposes and cross-domain applications. A characteristic of EO products is that they should undergo some data transformation for being considered decision-ready or inference-ready information.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • aka geophysical and biophysical parameters (surface temperature, leaf area index, etc.)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The earth spheres are divided into subsystems, these categories know as sphere, it’s defined as a collective of (physical) matter which share specific properties.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Martin, Y.E, et al 2012.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Something that has separate and distinct existence and objective or conceptual reality.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Expanded Uncertainty is the standard Uncertainty multiplied by a coverage factor, k. The coverage factor is chosen to obtain a desired level of confidence. Most commonly a 95% Confidence interval is chosen. For a Gaussian distribution, this is achieved with a coverage factor k = 2. (Note that strictly this provides a 95.45% Confidence interval).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Abstraction of real-world phenomena

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • A feature may occur as a type or an instance.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Translation of one form of Location into another.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Geocoding usually refers to the translation of "address" or "intersection" to "direct Position." Many services providers also include a "reverse geocoding" interface to their geocoder, thus extending the definition of the service as a general translator of Location. Because routing services use internal Location encodings not usually available to others, a geocoder is an integral part of the internals of such a service.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19133:2005; https://www.iso.org/standard/32551.html

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Geographic coordinate Reference system (CRS) that has a geodetic Reference frame and an ellipsoidal coordinate system.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Also known as geographic CRS.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Data with implicit or explicit Reference to a Location relative to the Earth.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Geographic Information is also used as a term for Information concerning phenomena implicitly or explicitly associated with a Location relative to the Earth.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: (Regular) Grid based on a geographic coordinate Reference system (CRS).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Spatial Reference in the form of a label or code that identifies a Location.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: • “Spain” is an example of a label (country name); “SW1-3AD” is an example of a code (postcode).

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Geopositioning an Object using a Physical Sensor Model or a True Replacement Model.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Determination of the geographic location of a >=2D feature(?).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19130-1:2018, 3.36 (‘geopositioning’), modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Information used to determine geographic Location.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Determination of the geographic Position of a point (0D) or linear (1D) Feature.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Modified from: ISO 19130-1:2018, 3.36

docs.title: Georectifying
docs.text: Synonyms: - Orthorectifying

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Correcting for positional displacement with respect to the surface of the Earth.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Source: ISO 19115-2:2019, 3.11; ISO 19115-2:2009(E); https://www.iso.org/standard/67039.html, modified

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: The correction of sample locations to achieve some sort of geometric regularity, e.g., a regular 2D geographic grid.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Consisting of, derived from, or relating to Data that is directly linked to specific geographical locations.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/geospatial
  • https://isotc211.geolexica.org/concepts/202/, accessed 20221010

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: the masses of minerals that constitute planet Earth.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Network composed of two or more sets of curves in which the members of each set intersect the members of the other sets in an algorithmic way.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The curves partition a space into grid cells.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The masses of liquid water, such as oceans, lakes, and rivers.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Guth et al. 2021

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: impact is regarded long-term according to X. However, in the Horizon Europe Missions terminology, impact is regarded short-term.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: ‘In-situ’ describes observations performed in the same Place where a Phenomenon occurs, normally without isolating it from other systems (its environment) or altering its pre-Observation state. The main Characteristic of such observations is that distance has no or only negligible (within Uncertainty) influence on the Value of the Property observed. In-situ observations therefore often require either direct physical contact or small distances between a Sensor and the observed Phenomenon.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Observations not fulfilling these conditions are considered Remote Sensing

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The result of organisation, interpretation, categorisation, classification, or some other form of processing of Data attaching to it a certain meaning that can be understood by the addressee.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Information depends on Data and is targeted.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The KCEO Glossary of Terms and Definitions serves as a reference for everyone involved in Earth Observation. We cover a wide range of terms, concepts, and definitions relevant to various EO disciplines such as remote sensing, satellite imagery, geospatial analysis, climate adaptation, and more. We strive to consolidate definitions where appropriate, while also acknowledging the necessity of their plurality when needed. Unlike many other online glossaries, our aim is to build an interactive and participative glossary for the EO community. As a living document, the KCEO Glossary of Terms and Definitions is in a constant state of evolution, continuously adapting while enabling full traceability.

docs.title: Resources & Reference Glossaries
docs.text:
• IPCC
  • UNTERM
  • GEOLEXICA OSGEO

  • ISO 19179-1:2021 Geographic information – Discrete Global Grid Systems Specifications – Part 1: Core Reference System and Operations, and Equal Area Earth Reference System

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Laboratory observations are (usually) in-situ observations in which the Object or Phenomenon is isolated from other systems or altered in its ‘original’ conditions or environment.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • It's important to consider that laboratory observations are typically conducted in controlled conditions, allowing for isolation or alteration of the object or phenomenon from its natural environment or other systems.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular Place referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• While a (geo)location identifies a geographic Place, it may also be associated with objects other than the Earth.
  • While location in principle covers 0- to 3-dimensional spatial geometries, it should not be used for 0- and 1-dimensional geometries (positions and paths)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Madrid
  • California

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19112:2019, (E), 3.1.3, modified, note 2 added

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular Quantity subject to Measurement.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A measurement is an Observation of a Quantity.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The process of collecting a measurement is called measuring.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • GEOGlos (VIM ?, modified)

    id_location(["<a href='../location'>Location</a>"]) --> id_geographic_data(["<a href='../geographic_data'>Geographic Data</a>"]);

    id_value(["<a href='../value'>Value</a>"]) --> id_band_central_wavelength(["<a href='../band_central_wavelength'>Band Central Wavelength</a>"]);
    id_value(["<a href='../value'>Value</a>"]) --> id_in-situ_observation(["<a href='../in-situ_observation'>In-situ Observation</a>"]);

    id_information(["<a href='../information'>Information</a>"]) --> id_geolocation_information(["<a href='../geolocation_information'>Geolocation Information</a>"]);

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: An, often numeric, theoretical (or otherwise abstract) representation of an Entity intended to generate Data describing one or more of its traits (as a result of pre-set conditions).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • The process of generating Data using a model is called modelling.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Entity with a well-defined boundary and identity that encapsulates state and behaviour.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC 19501:2005

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Observation (the process) is the act of determining the Value of Property by interacting with the Phenomenon using a Sensor. The obtained values are factual?( objective?, observational?) Data and are often themselves refeered to as observations (the results of the process).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• the observed Value is usually complemented by an Uncertainty
  • an observation (results) represents a Sample of Phenomenon (otherwise it would be identical with the Phenomenon)

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A line defined in an algorithmic way using at least two positions. (could be open ended) Alternative: A line connecting two positions in an algorithmic way. (limited by end points)

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • A path is a 1-dimensional place

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Particular era or span of time.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Periods are intervals named with a Period identifier.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Temporal Reference in the for of a label or code that identifies a Period.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Period identifiers are the temporal equivalent of geographic identifiers as specified in ISO 19912

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A phenomenon is an Entity that has a least one Property and is referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO, modified after Wikipedia and the Columbia Encyclopaedia 2008

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Part of any space referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A deliberate system of guidelines to guide decisions and achieve rational outcomes. A policy is a statement of intent and is implemented as a procedure or protocol. Policies are typically promulgated through official written documents.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A well-established concept, which is typically taught as the rational model of policy decision-making. It is an idealised view of the policy process.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ESA/CEOS?, modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: policy documents that represent the official written reference for a given Policy.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The process by which governments translate their political vision into programmes and actions to deliver 'outcomes' - desired change in the real world.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ESA/CEOS?, modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Policy milestones mark significant progress in addressing specific issues, or crucial decision points where significant choices are made. Concrete examples of policy milestones are: policy planning and proposing, impact assessment, implementation, or implementation cycles (e.g., Water Framework Directive, Marine Strategy Framework Directive), achievement of policy objectives and policy targets, evaluating evaluating and improvement of existing laws.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Desired outcome that policymakers wish to achieve.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Specific level or rate set for the policy objective.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A Place referenced by a single set of coordinates within a coordinate Reference system.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Opposite to (previous) ISO definition, position shall be used only for 0-dimensional primitives (points).

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO 19133:2005, modified to cover only points, also called ‘direct position’

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A process is a series or set of activities that interact to produce a result; it may occur once-only or be recurrent or periodic.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Wikipedia

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A Trait which is observable.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A Property whose instances can be compared by ratio or only by order.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • gEOGlos(VIM4 Notes omitted)

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: A Property that has a magnitude that can be expressed as a number from a continuous and contiguous range and a Reference.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC Guide 99:2007, 1.1, modified – Notes omitted

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A Phenomenon whose values for specific properties are known and understood with an Uncertainty significantly lower (quantify?) than that of the Observation with which it is compared.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: A sort of Data acquired with an Uncertainty significantly lower (quantify?) than that of the Data it is being compared with.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • VIM?, modified

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Remote sensing is a type of Observation performed at a significant distance from a Phenomenon.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• ‘Significant’ in this context means that the distance has, or may have, a non-negligible Impact on the Value of the Property observed.
  • The effect of the distance on the acquired Data is the main distinction criterion between ‘remote’ and ‘in-situ’ observations.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Enables other researchers to conduct an independent study with different Data and similar but not identical methods, yet arriving at results that confirm the original study’s hypothesis.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Craglia, M., ei al,. (2018).

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The quality or Characteristic of a Measurement or Observation to accurately represent a specific geographic Location, time Period, or environmental condition.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS metadata standard defines representativeness as the extent of the region around the Observation of which it is representative.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Is concerned with the validity of the results of that particular study, i.e., the possibility of readers to check whether results have been manipulated, by reproducing exactly the same study using the same Data and methods.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Ostermann and Granell (2015)

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Subset of one or more entities.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The subset may be spatial, temporal, spectral, or in any other dimension or attribute.
  • The process of obtaining a sample is called sampling.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A (technical?) device or instrument suited (through physical/chemical interaction) to measure one or more properties of a Phenomenon and thus collect factual/objective Data.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Sensing is therefore a synonym for Observation (the process).
  • As by their definition, sensors perform sampling.
  • Sensors used to obtain measurements must be calibrated and provide uncertainties.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Standard Uncertainty describes the standard deviation of the probability distribution describing the spread of possible values [in quantitative/continuous Data].

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: It indicates that the temporal statistical properties of the Sample depend only on the underlying physical processes and don’t depend on other factors such as fusing different products or sensors.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time Period used for reporting and for which the Information should be aggregated from the native Temporal Resolution.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h, 1 d second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • modified WIGOS Metadata Standard 2019

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The Observation or Model output representing regular intervals and specifying the length of the interval that determines the smallest event or process that can be resolved (e.g., the Period between observations, the time steps in a Model).

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • WIGOS 2019 distinguishes between sampling time Period, as the Period over which a Measurement is taken, and temporal sampling interval as the time Period between the beginning of consecutive sampling periods. Temporal resolution in this Glossary is equivalent to sampling time Period as used by WIGOS.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h, 1 m second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The interval between successive observations.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In remote sensing it is also called repeat cycle.
  • More generally it is known as temporal sampling interval.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1 s, 2 h second, hour, day, month, year

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The level of categorical detail of Information expressed by the number of classes.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • CGLS

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Uncertainty associated with the method of classification.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Typically, it is computed from the error matrix.
  • For a review of classification Uncertainty metrics, consult Ye et al. 2018.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time of the day that the variable or parameter is observed or simulated by a Model.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In remote sensing it is also known as time of overpass.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid unit timestamp 18:00 h (0-24) Hours timerange 18:00 – 20:00 h Hours

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: The time of the year that the variable is observed or simulated by a Model.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Type Entry format example Valid unit timestamp m/d Not Applicable timerange m/d - m/d Not Applicable

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Property of a Measurement result whereby the result can be related to a Reference through a documented unbroken chain of calibrations each contributing to the Measurement Uncertainty.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • https://www.isobudgets.com/Measurement-traceability-complying-iso-17025-requirements/

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A quality or Characteristic which is attributable to an Entity and referenced by an identifier.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Traits can be objective (inherent?) in which case they are also observable and called properties. Traits which are not observable (directly or indirectly) need to be assigned.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • Based on ISO 19143:2010, 4.21, ISO/IEC 2382:2015, 2121440, significantly modified, Note 1 added

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: A parameter, associated with the result of a Measurement, that characterises the dispersion of the values that could reasonably be attributed to the Measurand.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • GUM

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Non-negative parameter, associated with Data, which characterizes the dispersion of the values [of a Trait ]that could reasonably be attributed to a Phenomenon [by means of sensing or modelling].

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• In case of quantitative(continuous) Data the uncertainty may be, for example, a standard deviation (or a given multiple of it), or the half-width of an interval having a stated level of confidence. (see e.g. standard and Expanded Uncertainty)
  • For qualitative (categorical?) Data uncertainty may be, for example, expressed by commission and omission (‘confusion matrix’) or overall errors.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • modified from GUM, VIM4 :3.1, FIDUCEO, Notes added

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: Uncertainty is a measure of the spread of the distribution of possible values.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • FIDUCEO Glossary, VIM?, modified

docs.title: 4 Definition
docs.text: Parameter, associated with the result of Measurement, that characterizes the dispersion of values that could reasonably be attributed to the Measurand.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • When the quality of accuracy or precision of measured values, such as coordinates, is to be characterized quantitatively, the quality parameter is an estimate of the uncertainty of the Measurement results. Because accuracy is a qualitative concept, one should not use it quantitatively, that is associate numbers with it; numbers should be associated with measures of uncertainty instead.

docs.title: 5 Definition
docs.text: Parameter characterizing the dispersion of the values being attributed to a Measurand, based on the Information used.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • VIM4: 3.1

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: In the context of the KCEO, an Entity (person, organization, institution, etc.) that is requesting Data or Information with certain characteristics described by needs and/or requirements.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Process of assessing, by independent means, the quality of the Data products derived from the system outputs.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: Validation aims to verify that the specified requirements are achieved or compliant. This involves comparing mission products with representative Reference Data, considering various Observation conditions, ensuring the quality and Traceability of the Reference Data used.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • BIPM; QA4EO; ESA ?, modified

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: The assurance that a product, service, or system meets the needs of the customer and other identified stakeholders. It often involves acceptance and suitability with external customers.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • In this part of ISO 19159, the term validation is used in a limited sense and only relates to the validation of Calibration Data in order to control their change over time.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EU-US Land Imaging EO Collaboration

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Provision of objective evidence that a given item fulfils specified requirements.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• When applicable, Measurement Uncertainty should be taken into consideration.
  • The item may be, e.g. a process, Measurement procedure, material, compound, or measuring system.
  • The specified requirements may be, e.g. that a manufacturer's specifications are met.
  • Verification should not be confused with Calibration. Not every verification is a Validation.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • ISO/IEC Guide 99:2007, 2.44

docs.title: 2 Definition
docs.text: The evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or system complies with a regulation requirement, specification, or imposed condition. It is often an internal process.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • EU-US Land Imaging EO Collaboration

docs.title: 3 Definition
docs.text: Verification serves as a means to evaluate the reliability of the Data in the absence of a Reference dataset, allowing for an assessment of its standalone performance. It involves confirming the consistency and internal coherence of the Data without direct comparison to external Reference sources.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO

docs.title: 1 Definition
docs.text: Levels of a vertical discretization. Examples may be pressure levels in an atmospheric Model reanalysis or height levels in a forest biomass EO product.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Entry format example Valid unit 1, 5, 10 meter; 1000, 850, 500 hPa meter, hPa, unitless

docs.title: Sources
docs.text: • KCEO
